sub_topic: Find the volume form of a given metric.
message_1: Suppose we have the metric on $\mathbb{R}^3$ given by $ds^2 = dx^2 + 2 dy\,dz.$ Find the volume form of this metric.
message_2:
To find the volume form of the given metric, we first need to find the determinant of the metric tensor. The metric tensor $g$ for the given metric is:

$$
g = \begin{pmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & 0
\end{pmatrix}
$$

Now, we compute the determinant of the metric tensor:

$$
\det(g) = \begin{vmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & 0
\end{vmatrix} = 1(0 - 1) = -1
$$

The volume form is given by the square root of the absolute value of the determinant of the metric tensor, multiplied by the standard volume form in $\mathbb{R}^3$, which is $dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$. Therefore, the volume form for the given metric is:

$$
\sqrt{|\det(g)|} \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz = \sqrt{1} \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz = dx \wedge dy \wedge dz
$$

So, the volume form of the given metric is $dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$.
